Body: My questionI own an Android smartphone with a lithium-ion rechargeable battery.  I want the battery to remain at least somewhat useful as long as possible — even for five or ten years, if such a thing is attainable.(Other people aren't so careful; they have to buy a new battery after a few years.  But, as someone once pointed out to me, it's silly to buy a brand-new replacement battery for a phone which is already a few years old.)Battery charging generates heat.  (Source:  a New York Times article by Matthew L. Wald.)  If I use my phone while it's charging, things will heat up even more; would this be unhealthy for the battery?I use an app, BatteryBot Pro, which can alert me when my battery's state-of-charge surpasses a threshold of my choice.  When should I unplug my phone from its charger?[Edit:  An article by Isidor Buchmann of Cadex Electronics says I should stop charging the battery once it reaches reaches 3.92 V, or about 60% full.]How deeply can I discharge the battery?[Edit:  An article by Casey Johnston of Ars Technica, and another article by Charlie Messina of Relion Batteries, both agree:  When my battery falls to 20% full, I can avoid stressing the battery by recharging it instead of continuing to use it.]NoteSee also the related discussion I started at reddit.com.
Title: How to care for a lithium-ion battery so that it will remain useful for as many years as possible

history.Text: I own an Android smartphone with a lithium-ion battery.  I want its installed rechargeable battery to remain at least somewhat useful for five years, if possible.(Other people aren't so careful; they have to buy a new battery after a few years.  But it seems wasteful to shell out for a brand-new OEM battery for a cellphone which has already depreciated so much.)I read ["How to Prolong Lithium-based Batteries"](http://batteryuniversity.com/learn/article/how_to_prolong_lithium_based_batteries) but am still confused.  Maybe I need to read some more articles.  But let me try asking you folks instead.1.  For best results, when should I unplug it from its charger?  I guess once the battery reaches 3.92 V (about 60% full), correct?1.  Once I've charged the battery to this point, is it fine for me to keep on using the phone until the phone tells me "Battery is empty" and shuts itself off?  Or should I recharge it sooner than that — and, if so, how soon (at what state-of-charge) should I start charging the battery again?1.  If I use my phone while it's charging, this will generate additional heat.  Is this unhealthy for the battery?
I want my cellphone battery to remain useful for five years; please advise me on how to achieve such a feat
